keyTakeAways: A man convicted of sexual assault in college sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you' as part of a 12-step program, which reopened trauma for the victim.
The case highlights the systemic failure in campus sexual assault cases, where prosecutors often decline to file charges due to lack of evidence or institutional reluctance.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, spent over a decade pursuing justice, with evidence destroyed and time passing, illustrating the long-term emotional and legal toll on survivors.
Ian Cleary was extradited from France after being detained on a vagrancy charge, showing how legal systems can intersect across borders in pursuing justice.
The judge reduced the sentence below state guidelines due to Cleary’s guilty plea, remorse, and history of mental illness, indicating that mental health factors can influence sentencing.
The case underscores the importance of survivor advocacy and media exposure in bringing long-dormant cases to light.

namedEntities.name: Ian Cleary
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A man accused and convicted of sexually assaulting a college student at Gettysburg College in 2013. He was extradited from France in 2024 and sentenced in 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is central to the case, representing the perpetrator whose actions triggered a long legal and emotional journey for the victim and the broader issue of accountability in campus sexual assault.

namedEntities.name: Shannon Keeler
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The victim of the sexual assault at Gettysburg College in 2013. She pursued legal action for over a decade, eventually leading to prosecution after a 2019 Facebook message.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the primary survivor whose persistent advocacy brought the case to light, exposing systemic failures in campus sexual assault prosecution.

namedEntities.name: Gettysburg College
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Pennsylvania-based college where the sexual assault occurred in 2013 and where the victim was a first-semester student.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the location of the crime and a symbol of the institutional challenges in handling campus sexual assault cases, especially in terms of timely and effective prosecution.

namedEntities.name: France
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The country where Ian Cleary was detained in Metz on a vagrancy charge in 2024, leading to his extradition to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: France is significant because it represents the international dimension of the legal pursuit, showing how cross-border legal cooperation enables justice in complex cases.

namedEntities.name: Senior Judge Kevin Hess
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The judge who presided over the sentencing of Ian Cleary, acknowledging both the horror of the crime and the defendant's remorse.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His ruling reflects judicial discretion in sentencing, considering remorse, mental health, and the passage of time, offering insight into how courts balance accountability with rehabilitation.

namedEntities.name: Andrea Levy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Shannon Keeler’s lawyer who commented on the sentence being below expectations but relieved that the case is over.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She represents the legal support system for survivors and provides a critical perspective on the adequacy of the outcome for justice.

namedEntities.name: Tesla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A company where Ian Cleary worked after completing his college education in California.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It illustrates the trajectory of the perpetrator’s life post-assault, highlighting how he moved into high-profile industries after the crime.

namedEntities.name: Associated Press (AP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The news agency that published a 2021 story featuring Shannon Keeler's experience, which led to renewed attention and prosecution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The AP article played a pivotal role in prompting authorities to re-investigate the case, showing media’s power in advancing justice for survivors.

namedEntities.name: Adams County District Attorney Brian Sinnett
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The prosecutor who expressed doubt about Cleary's ability to evade justice, despite lack of direct proof.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents the legal side of the prosecution, showing the challenges in tracking down perpetrators who vanish from public view.

namedEntities.name: John Abom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Cleary's defense lawyer who argued that Cleary was homeless and unaware of the charges.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His argument underscores the complexity of mental health and homelessness in legal defense and the need for compassionate legal reasoning.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary, who sexually assaulted a woman at Gettysburg College in 2013, was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 after being extradited from France. The case, long delayed due to prosecutorial reluctance and lost evidence, gained momentum when the victim, Shannon Keeler, publicly shared her story in 2021, which led to renewed legal action. Cleary sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you' in 2019, reactivating Keeler’s pursuit of justice. The judge considered Cleary's guilty plea, remorse, and history of mental illness when reducing the sentence below state guidelines. The case illustrates systemic failures in campus sexual assault cases, including the destruction of evidence and the long time it takes for victims to receive accountability, and highlights the power of survivor advocacy and media exposure in achieving justice.
title: Man Sentenced in College Sexual Assault Case After 12-Year Pursuit
